title: On the quantum filtration of the Khovanov-Rozansky cohomology

title_detail.value: On the quantum filtration of the Khovanov-Rozansky cohomology

summary:
We prove the quantum filtration on the Khovanov-Rozansky link cohomology H_p
with a general degree (n+1) monic potential polynomial p(x) is invariant under
Reidemeister moves, and construct a spectral sequence converging to H_p that is
invariant under Reidemeister moves, whose E_1 term is isomorphic to the
Khovanov-Rozansky sl(n)-cohomology H_n. Then we define a generalization of the
Rasmussen invariant, and study some of its properties. We also discuss
relations between upper bounds of the self-linking number of transversal links
in the standard contact three sphere.

author: Hao Wu
fulltext:
arXiv:math/0612406v2 [math.GT] 14 Feb 2007

ON THE QUANTUM FILTRATION OF THE KHOVANOV-ROZANSKY
COHOMOLOGY
HAO WU
Abstract. We prove the quantum filtration on the Khovanov-Rozansky link cohomology Hp with a
general degree (n + 1) monic potential polynomial p(x) is invariant under Reidemeister moves, and
construct a spectral sequence converging to Hp that is invariant under Reidemeister moves, whose E1
term is isomorphic to the Khovanov-Rozansky sl(n)-cohomology Hn . Then we define a generalization
of the Rasmussen invariant, and study some of its properties. We also discuss relations between upper
bounds of the self-linking number of transversal links in standard contact S 3 .

1. Introduction and Statements of Results
For n ≥ 2, Khovanov and Rozansky [11] defined an invariant for links in S 3 known as the KhovanovRozansky sl(n)-cohomology Hn , which is a Z ⊕ Z-graded vector space, where one of the Z-grading is the
cohomological grading, and the other comes from the degree of polynomials, and is called the quantum
grading. Its construction is based on matrix factorizations with potential from xn+1 associated to certain
planar diagrams. When n = 2, their theory is equivalent to the Khovanov homology defined in [10]. When
using a non-homogeneous potential, the cohomological grading remains a Z-grading, while the quantum
grading degenerates into a filtration, which we call the quantum filtration, and denote by F . The works of
Lee [13] and Rasmussen [18] show that it is interesting to study Khovanov-Rozansky cohomologies defined
using a non-homogeneous polynomial. In [9], Gornik studied the Khovanov-Rozansky cohomology with
the potential xn+1 − (n + 1)β n x. Recently, Rasmussen [19] proved that, for any polynomial p(x), the
Khovanov-Rozansky cohomology Hp with potential p(x) is invariant as a Z-graded vector space under
braid-like Reidemeister moves, where the Z-grading is the cohomological grading. However, it was not
known if the quantum filtration on Hp is invariant under Reidemeister moves except in the special case of
the sl(n)-cohomology Hn , i.e. when p(x) = xn+1 . The main goal of this paper is to prove the invariance of
the quantum filtration under Reidemeister moves. This makes Hp a much more interesting link invariant.
All the links in this paper are in S 3 . For minor technical convenience, we work over the base field C
and consider only monic potential polynomials (so that we can cite the results of Khovanov and Rozansky
[11] and Gornik [9] without reformulate and re-prove them.) Note that the arguments and calculations
in [11] remain true over C.

Our method also gives us the following relation between the sl(n)-cohomology and the Hp cohomology,
which is a generalization of the corresponding result in [9].

By the definitions of sn and s, it is easy to see that s2 (K) = −s(K) for any knot K, where K is the

Theorem 1.6. Let p(x) = xn+1 − (n + 1)x. Then, for any link L in S 3 ,

where χs (L) is the slice Euler characteristic of L, i.e. the maximal Euler characteristic, χ(S), of an
oriented smoothly embedded compact surface F without closed components in D4 bounded by L.
Specially, |sn (K)| ≤ 2(n − 1)gs (K) for any knot K in S 3 , where gs (K) is the slice genus of K.

The proofs of Theorems 1.1, 1.2 and 1.3 are based on generalizations of methods developed by Khovanov and Rozansky in [11, 12]. We assume the readers are somewhat familiar with these papers. Some
understanding of Rasmussen's work in [19] would be useful too. In the treatment of slice Euler characteristic and the generalized Rasmussen invariants, we will use techniques developed by Gornik [9] and
Rasmussen [18].
The rest of this paper is organized as following. In section 2, we recall the construction of the KhovanovRozansky cohomology. Then we establish the MOY decompositions in section 3. Theorems 1.1, 1.2 and
1.3 are proved in section 4. Finally, in section 5, we discuss the generalized Rasmussen invariants and
prove Theorem 1.6.
Acknowledgments. The author would like to thank Mikhail Khovanov for many helpful discussions
and Bojan Gornik for answering some questions about [9]. He would like to thank Michael G. Sullivan
for his help on spectral sequences. He would also like to thank Marco Mackaay for helpful comments on
an earlier version of this paper.

2.3. Matrix factorizations associated to planer diagrams. To construct the Khovanov-Rozansky
cohomology, one considers the planar diagrams Γ with the following properties:
(1) Γ consists of two types of edges: regular edges and wide edges. These edges intersect only at
their endpoints.
(2) Regular edges are disjoint from each other. Wide edges are disjoint from each other.
(3) Each regular edge is oriented, and contains at least one marked point. Open endpoints of regular
edges are marked.
(4) Each wide edge has exactly two regular edges entering at one endpoint, and exactly two regular
edges exiting from the other endpoint.
Following [19], we call such a planar diagram a graph.

When Γ is closed, i.e. with no open endpoints, one can see that w(Γ) = 0, and Cp (Γ) is a Z2 -chain
complex. In this case, we denote by Hp (Γ) the cohomology of this chain complex. Note that the filtration
F on Cp (Γ) descends onto Hp (Γ). We call it the quantum filtration, and, again, denote it by F . More

 ON THE QUANTUM FILTRATION OF THE KHOVANOV-ROZANSKY COHOMOLOGY

13

specifically, an element of Hp (Γ) is in F k Hp (Γ) if and only if it is represented by a cocycle in F k Cp (Γ).
The Z2 -grading also descend onto Hp (Γ). For i ∈ Z2 , denote by Hpi (Γ) the R-submodule of Hp (Γ)
consists of elements with Z2 -degree i. Note that, by Proposition 22 of [11], Hp (Γ) is independent of the
marked points on Γ, i.e., given two different markings of the same closed graph, both of which satisfy
the conditions of at the beginning of this subsection, then there is a canonical isomorphism of the two
cohomologies computed by these two sets of markings, which preserves the Z2 -grading. By Proposition
2.16, this isomorphism also preserves the quantum filtration.
When p(x) = xn+1 , let Cn (Γ) = Cxn+1 (Γ), and, when Γ is closed, Hn (Γ) = Hxn+1 (Γ). In this case, the
Z-grading on Cn (Γ) descends onto Hn (Γ), which is called the quantum grading, and induces the quantum
filtration F on Hn (Γ). We denote by Hni,k (Γ) the subspace of Hn (Γ) consists of homogeneous elements
of Z2 -degree i and quantum degree k. (Note that Cn (Γ) is the matrix factorization C(Γ) defined in [11].)

Note that dχ is filtered under the quantum filtration. So Hp (D) inherits the quantum filtration from
H(Cp (D), dmf ), and Hp (D) admits a Z ⊕ Z2 -grading, where the Z-grading is the cohomological grading,
and the Z2 -grading comes from the cyclic chain complex (Cp (Γ), dmf ). The Z2 -grading is trivial in the
sense that the cohomology is always concentrated on the Z2 -degree equal to the Z2 -number of components
of D. Also, similar to [11, 12], we have that Hp (D) is independent of the markings on D as long as none
of the crossings is marked, and each arc between two crossings has a marked point. (See [14] for more
details.)

3. MOY Decompositions
Khovanov and Rozansky's proof of the invariance of the sl(n)-cohomology under Reidemeister moves is
based on several direct sum decompositions of the graph cohomology that correspond to Murakami, Ohtsuki and Yamada's recurrence relations of their graphic re-formulation of the SU (n)-HOMFLY polynomial
in [17]. Following Rasmussen [19], we call these direct sum decompositions the
PnMOY decompositions. In
this section, we fix an integer n ≥ 2 and a monic polynomial p(x) = xn+1 + i=0 ci xi , and establish the
MOY decompositions for the Hp cohomology.

4. Invariance
4.1. Filtered chain complexes. Recall that F is a filtration of a C-linear chain complex (C, d) of F is
a filtration of the underlying C-linear space C, and d is a filtered linear map under F . The cohomology
of a filtered chain complex inherits the filtration. A chain map f is a filtered isomorphism (resp. quasiisomorphism) of filtered chain complexes if f is an isomorphism (resp. quasi-isomorphism) of chain
complexes, and f and f −1 (resp. f∗ and f∗−1 ) are both filtered homomorphisms. In this case, we said
that the two filtered chain complexes are isomorphic (resp. quasi-isomorphic).

4.7. Link cobodisms. A cobodism from link L0 to link L1 is a properly smoothly embedded oriented
surface S in S 3 × [0, 1] such that ∂S = (−L0 × {0}) ⊔ (L1 × {1}), where −L0 is L0 with the opposite
orientation. A link cobodism is said to be elementary if it corresponds to either a Reidemeister move
or a Morse move (depicted in Figure 34). Any link cobodism admits a movie presentation, that is, a
decomposition into elementary cobodisms. Two movie presentations present the same cobodism if one
can be changed into the other by the movie moves depicted in Figures 59, 60 in [11]. (See [4, 5] for more
details.)

5. Slice Euler Characteristic and Generalized Rasmussen Invariants
The goal of this section is to prove Theorem 1.6. Our proof is based on Gornik's computations in
[9] and Rasmussen's arguments in [18]. Since Gornik's computations can be generalized to any monic
polynomial p(x) of degree n + 1 whose derivative p′ (x) has n distinct roots, our proof can be carried out
for any of such potentials. But, for simplicity, we work only with the potential polynomial xn+1 − (n + 1)x
and leave the general case to the readers. In the rest of this section, we fix n ≥ 2 and
p(x) = xn+1 − (n + 1)x.

Next, we want to understand how elementary cobodisms, i.e. Reidemeister moves and Morse moves,
affect this basis. The effects of Morse moves are easy to understand. The following proposition follows
easily from Lemmas 5.2 and 5.3.
Proposition 5.6. Let S be an elementary link cobodism from D to D′ , and Ψ : Hp (D) → Hp (D′ ) the
homomorphism induces by S.
(1) If S corresponds to a circle creation, then any state φ of D induces n states φj , j = 0, 1, * * * , n−1,
of D′ , where φj agrees with φ on components of D, and has value j on the new component, and
Pn−1
Ψ([fφ ]) = λ j=0 [fφj ] for some λ ∈ C \ {0}.
(2) If S corresponds to a circle annihilation, then any state φ of D induces a state φ′ of D′ which
agrees with φ on components of D′ , and Ψ([fφ ]) = μφ [fφ′ ] for some μφ ∈ C \ {0}.
(3) Assume that S corresponds to a saddle move. If the values of a state φ of D on the two strands
involved in the move are different, then Ψ([fφ ]) = 0. If the values of a state φ of D on the
two strands involved in the move are equal, including the case when the two strands belong to
the same component, then φ induces a state φ′ of D′ which agrees with φ on the unchanged
components, and takes the common value on the changed component(s), and Ψ([fφ ]) = νφ [fφ′ ]
for some νφ ∈ C \ {0}.
Proof. Note that the homomorphism induced by a Morse move commutes with the ξ0 -homomorphisms
used in the definition of fφ . So we can do the Morse move before we change the virtual crossings into
wide edges. Clearly, Lemmas 5.2 and 5.3 are applicable to planar diagrams with only virtual crossings.
And the proposition follows.

To understand the effect of Reidemeister move III, we need to consider graphs with both double wide
edges, i.e. the usual wide edges, and triple wide edges, i.e. wide edges with three regular edges entering
in one end and three regular edges exiting at the other end. (See Figure 24.) A state for such a graph
is still a function from the set of all regular edges to {0, 1, * * * , n − 1}. We say that a state φ of such a
graph Γ is admissible if both of the following statements are true.
(1) At every double wide edge in Γ, φ(e1 ) 6= φ(e2 ) and {φ(e1 ), φ(e2 )} = {φ(e3 ), φ(e4 )} where e1 , e2
are the two entering regular edges at this wide edge, and e3 , e4 are the two exiting regular edges;
(2) At every double wide edge in Γ, φ(e1 ), φ(e2 ), φ(e3 ) are pairwise distinct and {φ(e1 ), φ(e2 ), φ(e3 )} =
{φ(e4 ), φ(e5 ), φ(e6 )} where e1 , e2 and e3 are the three entering regular edges at this wide edge,
and e4 , e5 and e6 are the three exiting regular edges.

Proposition 5.9. If D and D′ are two link diagrams that differ by a Reidemeister move, then there is
a canonical 1-1 correspondence between the states of D and states of D′ such that, if φ and φ′ are states
of D and D′ corresponding to each other, and Ψ : Hp (D) → Hp (D′ ) is the isomorphism induced by the
Reidemeister move, then ∃ λφ ∈ C \ {0} with Ψ([fφ ]) = λφ [fφ′ ].

is compatible with the isomorphism induced by the Reidemeister move, we need to discuss the type of
the Reidemeister move involved.

We are now ready to generalize Rasmussen's arguments in [18]. Let S be a cobodism from link D
to link D′ , and (S1 , * * * , Sm ) a movie presentation of S, where each Sj is an elementary link cobodism.
Let Dj−1 and Dj be the initial and terminal ends of Sj . In particular, D0 = D and Dm = D′ . Define
S j = S1 ∪ * * * ∪ Sj , and Ψj = ΨSj ◦ * * * ◦ ΨS1 . S j is a cobodism from D = D0 to Dj . A component of Dj is
called evolved if it is a boundary component of a component of S j that contains at least one component

φ(k) if any two components of D ⊔ Dj contained in the same component of S j have the same value under
the function φ(k) ⊔ ψ. In particular, if ψ is compatible with φ(k) , then its value is k on every evolved
